sub_topic: Finding the velocity and acceleration of an object using calculus
message_1: A car is traveling along a straight road at a speed of 60 km/hr. The car starts to accelerate uniformly and after 10 seconds, it is traveling at a speed of 80 km/hr. What is the car's acceleration in m/s²? (1 km/hr = 0.2778 m/s)
message_2:
First, we need to convert the initial and final speeds from km/hr to m/s.

Initial speed (u) = 60 km/hr * 0.2778 m/s = 16.668 m/s
Final speed (v) = 80 km/hr * 0.2778 m/s = 22.224 m/s

The time taken (t) for the acceleration is given as 10 seconds.

We can use the formula for acceleration (a) in uniformly accelerated motion:

a = (v - u) / t

a = (22.224 m/s - 16.668 m/s) / 10 s

a = 5.556 m/s / 10 s

a = 0.5556 m/s²

The car's acceleration is 0.5556 m/s².
